content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Faculty of Law</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/183645" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>Faculty of Law</subtitle> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/183645</id> <updated>2015-03-12T02:54:20Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-12T02:54:20Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Managing without default retirement in universities: a comparative picture from Australia</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246884" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Blackham, Alysia</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246884</id> <updated>2015-02-19T10:40:45Z</updated> <published>2015-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Managing without default retirement in universities: a comparative picture from Australia Blackham, Alysia The abolition of the default retirement age is creating challenges for UK employers, and universities in particular. Operating without mandatory retirement may have consequences for performance management, the creation of opportunities for new generations of workers, the scope for workforce planning and employment costs. Drawing on comparative experiences of Australian universities, which have been operating without mandatory retirement since the 1990s, this article critically examines whether these consequences have materialised in Australia. It draws out a number of lessons for UK universities from the Australian experience. This is the accepted manuscript.  The paper is currently under embargo pending publication. </summary> <dc:date>2015-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Pursuing global justice through international criminal law: foreword</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246870" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Nouwen, Sarah M.H.</name> </author> <author> <name>Werner, Wouter G.</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246870</id> <updated>2015-02-18T14:30:23Z</updated> <published>2014-12-24T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Pursuing global justice through international criminal law: foreword Nouwen, Sarah M.H.; Werner, Wouter G. This is a pre-copyedited, author-produced PDF of an article accepted for publication in the Journal of International Criminal Justice following peer review. The version of record is available online at: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/jicj/mqu084 </summary> <dc:date>2014-12-24T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Monopolizing Global Justice: International Criminal Law as Challenge to Human Diversity</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246555" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Nouwen, Sarah M. H.</name> </author> <author> <name>Werner, Wouter G.</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246555</id> <updated>2015-01-12T11:41:28Z</updated> <published>2014-12-17T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Monopolizing Global Justice: International Criminal Law as Challenge to Human Diversity Nouwen, Sarah M. H.; Werner, Wouter G. Over the past two decades, international criminal law has been increasingly institutionalized and has become one of the dominant frames for defining issues of justice and conflict resolution. Indeed, international criminal law is often presented as the road towards global justice. But the rise of international criminal law and its equation with global justice come with a profound risk: alternative conceptions of justice can be marginalized. Based on field work in Uganda and Sudan, we present five examples of alternative conceptions of justice that in fact have been side-lined: the restoration of relationships, putting an end to on-going violence, redistribution, non-criminal law forms of punishment and equality. However, international criminal law\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds monopolization of discourses of justice threatens not only alternative conceptions of justice, but also international criminal law itself. It frustrates one of its main aims: the protection of diversity. This is the accepted manuscript. The final version is available from OUP at http://jicj.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2014/12/17/jicj.mqu078.full. </summary> <dc:date>2014-12-17T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Elusive Certainty: Implications of Donegal v Zambia</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246410" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Waibel, Michael</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246410</id> <updated>2014-11-19T15:44:50Z</updated> <published>2007-07-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Elusive Certainty: Implications of Donegal v Zambia Waibel, Michael This is the final published version of the article. It was originally published by Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC in International Financial Law Review and can be found online here: http://www.iflr.com/Article/1977093/IFLR-magazine/Elusive-certainty.html. </summary> <dc:date>2007-07-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
